metadata.titleEn: PML_V2 global evapotranspiration and gross primary production (2002.07-2019.08)
metadata.description:
PML_V2 terrestrial evapotranspiration and total primary productivity dataset, including gross primary product (GPP), vegetation transpiration (Ec), soil evaporation (Es), vaporization of intercepted rainfall , Ei) and water body, ice and snow evaporation (ET_water), a total of 5 elements. The data format is tiff, the space-time resolution is 8 days, 0.05°, and the time span is 2002.07-2019.08.

Based on the Penman-Monteith-Leuning (PML) model, PML_V2 is coupled to the GPP process based on stomatal conductance theory. GPP and ET mutually restrict and restrict each other, which makes PML_V2 in ET simulation accuracy, which is greatly improved compared with the previous model. The parameters of PML_V2 are divided into different vegetation types and are determined on 95 vorticity-related flux stations around the world. The parameters were then migrated globally according to the MODIS MCD12Q2.006 IGBP classification. PML_V2 uses GLDAS 2.1 meteorological drive and MODIS leaf area index (LAI), reflectivity (Albedo), emissivity (Emissivity) as inputs, and finally obtains PML_V2 terrestrial evapotranspiration and total primary productivity data sets.
metadata.instructions: The data is stored in TIFF format. The file name is "yyyy mm dd.tif", such as 2002-07-04.tif, which corresponds to GPP and ET in the 8 days from 2002-07-04 to 2002-07-11.

authorList.unitEn: Institute of Geographic Sciences and Natural Resources Research, Chinese Academy of Sciences

background: Terrestrial evapotranspiration (ET) is the sum of evaporation from the soil, Es, transpiration from the plant canopy, Et, and evaporation of precipitation intercepted by the vegetation, Ei. Among the three components, Et is coupled with carbon assimilation (or gross primary productivity (GPP)), forming the two dominant processes in global water and carbon cycles. Better understanding of these interrelated processes will improve our ability to manage water and carbon resources. ET forms the second largest water flux within the terrestrial hydrological cycle, accounting for about 60–70% of precipitation globally. GPP is produced during photosynthesis and provides a key source of food and energy to sustain the vast majority of life on Earth. Therefore, it is critical to accurately estimate global ET and GPP under climate change and land-cover change. Remote Sensing (RS)-based ET models are dominant for regional and global ET estimations in the past few decades. Among those models, the approaches that combine the Penman-Monteith (PM) equation with remotely-sensed LAI data have been shown to be biophysically robust. The main focus of the PM-based modelling framework is the accurate estimate of the surface conductance (Gs), which describes the canopy-soil conductance to water flux.
research objective: Building on the previous PML studies, this study aims to further improve PML-V2 model structure, develop global parameterisation schemes, and build this model within GEE to estimate coupled ET and GPP, and ecosystem water use efficiency (GPP divided by ET) globally using the climatic (GLDAS) and 500m resolution MODIS (LAI, albedo, and surface emissivity) data.
challenges: There are two obvious data-related uncertainty sources. First, there are some PFTs with limited flux sites, such as MF with 2 and OSH with 4. Second, uncertainty in land-cover type classification influences parameterisation and accuracy of global GPP and ET mapping. This study did not consider nutrient stress on GPP and ET constraint, which could lead to overestimation of global GPP.
methods: Here we estimate 8-day global ET and gross primary production (GPP) at 500m resolution from July 2002 to December 2017 using a coupled diagnostic biophysical model (called PML-V2) that, built using Google Earth Engine, takes MODIS data (leaf area index, albedo, and emissivity) together with GLDAS meteorological forcing data as model inputs. PML-V2 is well calibrated against 8-day measurements at 95 widely-distributed flux towers for 10 plant functional types, indicated by Root Mean Square Error (RMSE) and Bias being 0.69 mm d−1 and −1.8% for ET respectively, and being 1.99 gC m−2 d−1 and 4.2% for GPP.
dataset: The 0.25° resolution and 3-hour GLDAS-2.1 meteorological forcings (Rodell and Beaudoing, 2016) from 2002 to 2017, including precipitation, air temperature, vapor pressure, shortwave downward radiation, longwave downward radiation and wind speed, were used to drive the PML-V2 model. Monthly atmospheric CO2 concentration data were obtained from NOAA globally averaged marine surface monthly mean data. All remote sensing data were obtained from GEE MODIS collection 6 products from 4 July 2002 to 31 December 2017. There were 95 global flux sites (Fig.2) from FLUXNET2015 (http://fluxnet.fluxdata.org/data/fluxnet2015-dataset/) used to evaluate the PML-V2 model that observed both ET and GPP.
findings: Our estimates show that global ET and GPP both significantly (p < 0.05) increased over the past 15 years. Our results demonstrate it is very promising to use the coupled PML-V2 model to improve estimates of GPP, ET and water use efficiency, and its uncertainty can be further reduced by improving model inputs, model structure and parameterisation schemes.

Verification.Question: Is the accuracy of global GPP and ET mapping influenced by the uncertainty in land-cover type classification?

Disjunctive.Question: Which data collection approach is more utilized in the evaluation of biophysical models for estimating GPP and ET: FLUXNET site measurements, atmospheric CO2 concentration data, or GLDAS meteorological forcings?

Concept Completion.Question: What are the primary data sources used to drive a biophysical model for estimating global ET and GPP?
Where are the flux sites located that are used to evaluate the performance of a global ET and GPP model?
What are the main challenges in parameterizing models for global GPP and ET mapping?
Concept Completion.Answer: limited flux sites, uncertainty in land-cover type classification

Example.Question: What is an example of a challenge faced in parameterizing global ET and GPP models?
Example.Answer: One example of a challenge in parameterizing global ET and GPP models is the uncertainty in land-cover type classification, which influences the accuracy of global GPP and ET mapping. Another challenge is the limited number of flux sites for certain plant functional types (PFTs), which can affect the calibration of the model.

Example.Question: Could you provide an example of a dataset used to drive a global ET and GPP estimation model?
Example.Answer: An example of a dataset used to drive a global ET and GPP estimation model includes the 0.25° resolution and 3-hour GLDAS-2.1 meteorological forcings, which consist of data on precipitation, air temperature, vapor pressure, shortwave downward radiation, longwave downward radiation, and wind speed.

Feature Specification.Question: What specific challenges influence the accuracy of global parameterization schemes for terrestrial evapotranspiration and gross primary productivity models?
Feature Specification.Answer: limited flux sites for some plant functional types, uncertainty in land-cover type classification, nutrient stress on GPP and ET constraint not considered

Feature Specification.Question: What are the key features of the meteorological forcings used in the data collection process for terrestrial evapotranspiration and gross primary productivity estimation?
Feature Specification.Answer: 0.25° resolution, 3-hour GLDAS-2.1 data, 2002 to 2017, precipitation, air temperature, vapor pressure, shortwave downward radiation, longwave downward radiation, wind speed

Quantification.Question: How many flux sites were used to calibrate the global parameterization schemes in a data collection method?

Comparison.Question: How do data collection methods using remote sensing in terrestrial evapotranspiration models compare to traditional ground-based methods in terms of accuracy and data resolution?
Comparison.Answer: Remote sensing-based methods, like those used in PML-V2, leverage MODIS data for inputs such as leaf area index, albedo, and emissivity, offering high spatial resolution (500m) and temporal frequency (8-day intervals). These approaches are biophysically robust, especially when combined with the Penman-Monteith equation, in contrast to traditional ground-based methods that may offer higher accuracy at localized scales but lack global coverage and temporal frequency.

Comparison.Question: What are the similarities and differences between using PML-V2 and other remote sensing models for estimating global gross primary productivity (GPP) and terrestrial evapotranspiration (ET)?
Comparison.Answer: PML-V2 and other remote sensing models often use similar inputs like MODIS and GLDAS data; however, PML-V2 integrates a coupled diagnostic biophysical model that enhances ET and GPP estimation accuracy by accounting for the interdependency of these processes. The model is well-calibrated against measurements from flux towers, which may not be the case for other models. PML-V2 shows improved precision in surface conductance estimation, crucial for accurate ET and GPP mapping.

Comparison.Question: In what ways do data-related uncertainties differ between global parameterization schemes and localized calibration methods in terrestrial evapotranspiration and GPP models?
Comparison.Answer: Global parameterization schemes, like those used in PML-V2, face uncertainties primarily from limited flux site data for certain plant functional types and inaccuracies in land-cover classification. Localized calibration methods may have higher accuracy due to site-specific adjustments but lack the scalability and broad applicability of global models, which are crucial for consistent global mapping of ET and GPP.

Interpretation.Question: What implications could the use of remotely-sensed LAI data in combination with the Penman-Monteith equation have on the accuracy and reliability of evapotranspiration models?
Interpretation.Answer: The combination of remotely-sensed LAI data with the Penman-Monteith equation is shown to be biophysically robust for estimating surface conductance, which is crucial for accurate ET modelling. This approach enhances the model's ability to estimate coupled ET and GPP, potentially improving the management of global water and carbon resources.

Interpretation.Question: How might the uncertainties related to land-cover type classification and limited flux site data influence the parameterization and accuracy of global GPP and ET mapping?
Interpretation.Answer: Uncertainties in land-cover type classification and limited flux site data can affect the parameterization and accuracy of global GPP and ET mapping. For instance, some plant functional types (PFTs) have limited flux sites, which could lead to less accurate parameterization. Furthermore, incorrect land-cover classifications might result in errors in mapping GPP and ET, potentially leading to overestimation or underestimation of these components.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What factors contribute to data-related uncertainties in estimating global terrestrial evapotranspiration and gross primary production?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: There are two obvious data-related uncertainty sources: the limited number of flux sites for some plant functional types, and the uncertainty in land-cover type classification, which influences parameterisation and accuracy of global GPP and ET mapping.

Causal Antecedent.Question: Why is it challenging to accurately parameterize global models for terrestrial evapotranspiration and gross primary production?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: The challenge in accurately parameterizing global models arises from limited flux site data for some plant functional types and the influence of land-cover type classification on parameterisation. Additionally, not considering nutrient stress on GPP and ET can lead to overestimation of global GPP.

Causal Consequence.Question: What are the potential consequences of using the coupled Penman-Monteith-Leuning model for global parameterisation schemes on the accuracy of evapotranspiration and gross primary productivity estimations?
Causal Consequence.Answer: The use of the coupled Penman-Monteith-Leuning model for global parameterisation schemes is likely to improve the accuracy of evapotranspiration (ET) and gross primary productivity (GPP) estimations by enhancing the simulation precision of ET and GPP processes. The model's structure, which accounts for the interdependence of these processes, allows for better estimation of global ET and GPP, contributing to a deeper understanding of water and carbon cycles.

Causal Consequence.Question: What could be the impact of data-related uncertainties, such as limited flux sites for certain plant functional types and land-cover classification inaccuracies, on the global mapping of GPP and ET?
Causal Consequence.Answer: Data-related uncertainties, such as having limited flux sites for certain plant functional types and inaccuracies in land-cover classification, may lead to challenges in accurately parameterizing and mapping global gross primary productivity (GPP) and evapotranspiration (ET). These uncertainties can potentially affect the reliability and precision of the global estimates, possibly resulting in overestimations or underestimations of GPP and ET.

Causal Consequence.Question: How might the integration of remote sensing data from MODIS and meteorological data from GLDAS influence the effectiveness of a biophysical model in estimating global ecosystem water use efficiency?
Causal Consequence.Answer: Integrating remote sensing data from MODIS and meteorological data from GLDAS can significantly enhance the effectiveness of a biophysical model in estimating global ecosystem water use efficiency. The combination of high-resolution MODIS data, including leaf area index, albedo, and surface emissivity, with GLDAS meteorological inputs, provides comprehensive and accurate input data that improve the model's predictions of ecosystem water use efficiency, defined as the ratio of GPP to ET.

Goal Orientation.Question: What is the primary objective of developing global parameterization schemes for estimating coupled ET and GPP in terrestrial ecosystems?
Goal Orientation.Answer: Building on previous PML studies, the primary objective is to further improve the PML-V2 model structure, develop global parameterization schemes, and estimate coupled ET and GPP, along with ecosystem water use efficiency globally using climatic data and high-resolution MODIS data.

Goal Orientation.Question: What goals are associated with assessing uncertainties in land-cover type classification for global GPP and ET mapping?
Goal Orientation.Answer: The goals associated with assessing uncertainties in land-cover type classification are to minimize inaccuracies in the parameterization and mapping of global GPP and ET, as these uncertainties can influence the reliability of the model outputs and potentially lead to overestimations, especially when nutrient stress is not considered.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What procedures are involved in calibrating a biophysical model like PML-V2 against measurements from flux towers for estimating terrestrial evapotranspiration and gross primary productivity?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: The calibration of a biophysical model like PML-V2 involves using measurements from 95 widely-distributed flux towers for 10 plant functional types. The model is calibrated by comparing its outputs against 8-day measurements, ensuring accuracy through metrics such as Root Mean Square Error (RMSE) and Bias, which are used to evaluate the model's performance for ET and GPP.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: How is the Penman-Monteith-Leuning model integrated with remote sensing data to improve the accuracy of global evapotranspiration and gross primary productivity estimation?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: The integration of the Penman-Monteith-Leuning model with remote sensing data involves using remotely-sensed MODIS data, such as leaf area index, albedo, and emissivity, along with GLDAS meteorological forcing data. This combination allows for a more accurate estimation of evapotranspiration and gross primary productivity by coupling these datasets within a biophysical model framework.

Enablement.Question: What methodologies enable the calibration of biophysical models like PML-V2 using data from diverse plant functional types across global flux sites?
Enablement.Answer: The calibration of biophysical models such as PML-V2 is enabled by using measurements from 95 widely-distributed flux towers that represent 10 plant functional types. These flux towers provide 8-day measurements used to evaluate the model's accuracy, indicated by Root Mean Square Error (RMSE) and Bias metrics for both ET and GPP.

Expectation.Question: Why might the combination of the Penman-Monteith equation with remotely-sensed LAI data be expected to enhance the accuracy of surface conductance estimates in global ET models?
Expectation.Answer: The combination of the Penman-Monteith equation with remotely-sensed LAI data is expected to enhance the accuracy of surface conductance estimates because it allows for a more biophysically robust approach, focusing on the accurate estimation of canopy-soil conductance to water flux, which is crucial for regional and global ET estimations.

Expectation.Question: Why could uncertainties arise in parameterizing a global dataset using plant functional types (PFTs) from limited flux sites?
Expectation.Answer: Uncertainties could arise in parameterizing a global dataset using plant functional types from limited flux sites due to the insufficient representation of certain PFTs, such as MF with only 2 and OSH with 4 flux sites, which can affect the accuracy and parameterization of global GPP and ET mapping.

Expectation.Question: What expectations might researchers have regarding the use of Google Earth Engine for developing global parameterization schemes in ET and GPP estimation models?
Expectation.Answer: Researchers might expect that using Google Earth Engine for developing global parameterization schemes will facilitate the estimation of coupled ET and GPP, leveraging high-resolution MODIS data and climatic inputs to improve model accuracy and water use efficiency assessments on a global scale.

Judgmental.Question: In what ways could the consideration of nutrient stress improve the accuracy of global GPP and ET estimations?
Judgmental.Answer: Incorporating nutrient stress could improve the accuracy of global GPP and ET estimations by potentially reducing the overestimation of GPP, which was not considered in the current data collection approach, thereby making the model more reflective of actual environmental conditions.

Assertion.Question: I'm not sure what challenges exist in accurately mapping global GPP and ET using remote sensing techniques.
Assertion.Answer: Challenges in accurately mapping global GPP and ET include data-related uncertainties such as limited flux sites for some plant functional types and inaccuracies in land-cover type classification, which affect parameterization and mapping accuracy. Additionally, nutrient stress on GPP and ET, which wasn't considered, could lead to overestimation.

Request/Directive.Question: Please identify and discuss the primary challenges faced in data collection and parameterization when estimating global ET and GPP.
Request/Directive.Answer: One of the main challenges in data collection and parameterization is the limited number of flux sites available for certain plant functional types, such as MF and OSH, which impacts the model's calibration accuracy. Additionally, uncertainties in land-cover type classification can affect the parameterization and accuracy of global GPP and ET mapping. There is also a consideration of nutrient stress, which was not factored into the model and could result in an overestimation of global GPP.
